mil3.7.3:0.3: 3. Question on Striving for the Removal of Past Suffering
mil3.7.3:1.2: “Venerable Nāgasena, are you striving for the abandonment of past suffering?”
mil3.7.3:1.4: “Then, venerable sir, are you striving for the abandonment of future suffering?”
mil3.7.3:1.6: “Then, venerable sir, are you striving for the abandonment of present suffering?”
mil3.7.3:1.8: “If you are not striving for the abandonment of past suffering, nor for the abandonment of future suffering, nor for the abandonment of present suffering, then what are you striving for?”
mil3.7.3:1.10: “Your majesty, I am striving so that this suffering would cease and that no other suffering would arise.”
mil3.7.3:2.1: “Is there now, venerable Nāgasena, future suffering for you?”
mil3.7.3:2.3: “Indeed, venerable Nāgasena, you are very wise that you strive for abandoning future suffering that is not existing.”
mil3.7.3:2.4: “Are there, your majesty, any opposing kings, that are adversaries, that have risen up against you?”
mil3.7.3:2.6: “Is it then, your majesty, that you had a moat dug, a rampart put up, and a gateway and watchtower constructed?”
mil3.7.3:2.7: “Certainly not, venerable sir, these were prepared previously.”
mil3.7.3:2.8: “Is it then, your majesty, that you would train in elephant warfare, in horse warfare, in chariot warfare, in archery, and in swordsmanship?”
mil3.7.3:2.9: “Certainly not, venerable sir, I had trained in these previously.”
mil3.7.3:2.11: “In order to prevent future perils, venerable sir.”
mil3.7.3:2.12: “Is there a future peril now, your majesty?”
mil3.7.3:2.14: “Indeed, your majesty, you are very wise that you would prepare for the prevention of a future peril that is not existing.”
mil3.7.3:3.2: “What do you think, your majesty, when you might become thirsty is it then that you would have a well, a pond, or a reservoir dug, thinking, ‘I will drink water’?”
mil3.7.3:3.3: “Certainly not, venerable sir, this has been arranged for previously.”
mil3.7.3:3.5: “It has been arranged, venerable sir, in order to prevent future thirst.”
mil3.7.3:3.6: “Is there a future thirst now, your majesty?”
mil3.7.3:3.8: “Indeed, your majesty, you are very wise that you would prepare for the prevention of a future thirst that is not existing.”
mil3.7.3:4.2: “What do you think, your majesty, when you might become hungry is it then that you would have a field ploughed, and rice sowed, thinking, ‘I will eat food?”
mil3.7.3:4.3: “Certainly not, venerable sir, this has been arranged for previously.”
mil3.7.3:4.5: “In order, venerable sir, to prevent future hunger.”
mil3.7.3:4.6: “Is there a future hunger now, your majesty?”
mil3.7.3:4.8: “Indeed, your majesty, you are very wise that you would prepare for the prevention of a future hunger that is not existing.”
mil3.7.3:6.1: Question on Striving for the Abandonment of Suffering third
